subjectLabel:
Edit for the correct use of written Standard American English, including
  • capitalization
      • – proper nouns,
      – initials of a person's name,
      – courtesy titles (Mr., Ms.),
      – days of the week,
      – months of the year, and
      – titles of books, poems, and songs;
  • punctuation
      • – apostrophes in contractions,
      – commas in a series,
      – commas in dates, and
      – quotation marks to show someone is speaking; and
  • spelling
      • – words that do not fit regular spelling patterns (for example, was, were, says, said),
      – high-frequency words, and
      – basic short-vowel, long-vowel, r-controlled, and consonant-blend patterns.
(See Instructional Appendix: High-Frequency Words.)
objectLabel: Recognize and read grade-appropriate irregularly spelled words.

objectLabel: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.

subjectLabel:
Edit for the correct use of written Standard American English, including
  • capitalization
      • – geographic names,
      – holidays, and
      – historical and special events;
  • punctuation
      • – commas in addresses,
      – commas in the greeting and closing of letters,
      – commas in compound sentences,
      – apostrophes in contractions and possessive nouns,
      – periods in abbreviations, and
      – indentation of paragraphs; and
  • spelling
      • – misused homonyms,
      – high-frequency multisyllabic words,
      – words that have blends,
      – contractions,
      – compound words, and
      – orthographic patterns (for example, qu, consonant doubling, changing the ending of a word from -y to -ies when forming the plural).
(See Instructional Appendix: Composite Writing Matrix.)

subjectLabel: Analyze a given literary text to make, revise, and confirm predictions and draw conclusions.

subjectLabel: Analyze the relationship among characters, setting, and plot in a given literary text.

subjectLabel: Recognize the characteristics of poetry (including stanza, rhyme, and repetition).

subjectLabel: Read independently for extended periods of time for pleasure.

subjectLabel: Follow multistep directions.

objectLabel: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.

subjectLabel:
Edit for the correct use of written Standard American English, including
  • capitalization
      • – proper nouns,
      – initials of a person's name,
      – courtesy titles (Mr., Ms.),
      – days of the week,
      – months of the year, and
      – titles of books, poems, and songs;
  • punctuation
      • – apostrophes in contractions,
      – commas in a series,
      – commas in dates, and
      – quotation marks to show someone is speaking; and
  • spelling
      • – words that do not fit regular spelling patterns (for example, was, were, says, said),
      – high-frequency words, and
      – basic short-vowel, long-vowel, r-controlled, and consonant-blend patterns.
(See Instructional Appendix: High-Frequency Words.)
objectLabel: Consult reference materials, including beginning dictionaries, as needed to check and correct spellings.

objectLabel: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.

subjectLabel:
Edit for the correct use of written Standard American English, including
  • capitalization
      • – geographic names,
      – holidays, and
      – historical and special events;
  • punctuation
      • – commas in addresses,
      – commas in the greeting and closing of letters,
      – commas in compound sentences,
      – apostrophes in contractions and possessive nouns,
      – periods in abbreviations, and
      – indentation of paragraphs; and
  • spelling
      • – misused homonyms,
      – high-frequency multisyllabic words,
      – words that have blends,
      – contractions,
      – compound words, and
      – orthographic patterns (for example, qu, consonant doubling, changing the ending of a word from -y to -ies when forming the plural).
(See Instructional Appendix: Composite Writing Matrix.)
objectLabel: Use spelling patterns and generalizations (e.g., word families, position-based spellings, syllable patterns, ending rules, meaningful word parts) in writing words.

subjectLabel:
Edit for the correct use of written Standard American English, including
  • capitalization
      • – geographic names,
      – holidays, and
      – historical and special events;
  • punctuation
      • – commas in addresses,
      – commas in the greeting and closing of letters,
      – commas in compound sentences,
      – apostrophes in contractions and possessive nouns,
      – periods in abbreviations, and
      – indentation of paragraphs; and
  • spelling
      • – misused homonyms,
      – high-frequency multisyllabic words,
      – words that have blends,
      – contractions,
      – compound words, and
      – orthographic patterns (for example, qu, consonant doubling, changing the ending of a word from -y to -ies when forming the plural).
(See Instructional Appendix: Composite Writing Matrix.)

subjectLabel:
Edit for the correct use of written Standard American English, including
  • capitalization
      • – titles of works of art,
      – titles of magazines and newspapers,
      – brand names,
      – proper adjectives, and
      – names of organizations;
  • punctuation
      • – quotation marks to indicate direct quotations or dialogue,
      – quotation marks to indicate titles of works (for example, articles, reports, chapters, and other short pieces) published within separately published works,
      – between main clauses, and
      – underlining or italics to indicate titles of separately published works (for example, books and magazines); and
  • spelling
      • – words with suffixes and
      – prefixes and multisyllabic words.
(See Instructional Appendix: Composite Writing Matrix.)
objectLabel: Spell grade-appropriate words correctly, consulting references as needed.

objectLabel: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.

subjectLabel:
Edit for the correct use of written Standard American English, including
  • capitalization
      • – proper nouns,
      – initials of a person's name,
      – courtesy titles (Mr., Ms.),
      – days of the week,
      – months of the year, and
      – titles of books, poems, and songs;
  • punctuation
      • – apostrophes in contractions,
      – commas in a series,
      – commas in dates, and
      – quotation marks to show someone is speaking; and
  • spelling
      • – words that do not fit regular spelling patterns (for example, was, were, says, said),
      – high-frequency words, and
      – basic short-vowel, long-vowel, r-controlled, and consonant-blend patterns.
(See Instructional Appendix: High-Frequency Words.)

subjectLabel:
Edit for the correct use of written Standard American English, including
  • capitalization
      • – proper nouns,
      – initials of a person's name,
      – courtesy titles (Mr., Ms.),
      – days of the week,
      – months of the year, and
      – titles of books, poems, and songs;
  • punctuation
      • – apostrophes in contractions,
      – commas in a series,
      – commas in dates, and
      – quotation marks to show someone is speaking; and
  • spelling
      • – words that do not fit regular spelling patterns (for example, was, were, says, said),
      – high-frequency words, and
      – basic short-vowel, long-vowel, r-controlled, and consonant-blend patterns.
(See Instructional Appendix: High-Frequency Words.)
objectLabel: Spell grade-appropriate words correctly, consulting references as needed.

      – commas in a series,
      – commas in dates, and
      – quotation marks to show someone is speaking; and
  • spelling
      • – words that do not fit regular spelling patterns (for example, was, were, says, said),
      – high-frequency words, and
      – basic short-vowel, long-vowel, r-controlled, and consonant-blend patterns.
(See Instructional Appendix: High-Frequency Words.)

subjectLabel: Analyze the relationship among character, plot, conflict, and theme in a given literary text.
objectLabel: Analyze how particular lines of dialogue or incidents in a story or drama propel the action, reveal aspects of a character, or provoke a decision.

subjectLabel: Analyze a given literary text to determine its theme.
objectLabel: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to the characters, setting, and plot; provide an objective summary of the text.

subjectLabel: Analyze literary texts to draw conclusions and make inferences.
objectLabel: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.

subjectLabel: Explain the effect of point of view on a given literary text.
objectLabel: Analyze how an author develops and contrasts the points of view of different characters or narrators in a text.

subjectLabel: Understand the characteristics of poetry (including stanza, rhyme scheme, repetition, and refrain) and drama (including stage directions and the use of monologues).
objectLabel: Analyze how a drama's or poem's form or structure (e.g., soliloquy, sonnet) contributes to its meaning.

subjectLabel: Interpret the connotations of words to understand the meaning of a given text.
objectLabel: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of rhymes and other repetitions of sounds (e.g., alliteration) on a specific verse or stanza of a poem or section of a story or drama.

subjectLabel: Interpret devices of figurative language (including simile, metaphor, personification, and hyperbole) and sound devices (including onomatopoeia and alliteration).

subjectLabel: Compare/contrast literary texts from various genres (for example, poetry, drama, novels, and short stories).
objectLabel: Compare and contrast a fictional portrayal of a time, place, or character and a historical account of the same period as a means of understanding how authors of fiction use or alter history.

subjectLabel: Read independently for extended periods of time for pleasure.

subjectLabel: Analyze central ideas within and across informational texts.

subjectLabel: Interpret the connotations of words to understand the meaning of a given text.

subjectLabel: Interpret the effect of the author's craft (for example, word choice, sentence structure, the use of figurative language, and the use of dialogue) on the meaning of literary texts.

subjectLabel: Identify author bias (for example, word choice and the exclusion and inclusion of particular information).

subjectLabel: Analyze the impact that text elements (for example, print styles and chapter headings) have on the meaning of a given informational text.

subjectLabel: Analyze literary texts to draw conclusions and make inferences.

subjectLabel: Compare/contrast literary texts from various genres (for example, poetry, drama, novels, and short stories).

subjectLabel: Explain the effect of point of view on a given literary text.

subjectLabel: Analyze the effect of the author's craft (including tone and the use of imagery, flashback, foreshadowing, symbolism, irony, and allusion) on the meaning of literary texts.

subjectLabel: Read independently for extended periods of time for pleasure.
objectLabel: By the end of the year, read and comprehend literature, including stories, dramas, and poems, in the grades 6—8 text complexity band proficiently, with scaffolding as needed at the high end of the range.

subjectLabel: Compare/contrast information within and across texts to draw conclusions and make inferences.
objectLabel: Cite the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.

subjectLabel: Use context clues (for example, those that provide an example, a definition, a restatement, or a comparison/contrast) to generate the meanings of unfamiliar and multiple-meaning words.
objectLabel: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.

subjectLabel: Analyze the effect of the author's craft (including tone and the use of imagery, flashback, foreshadowing, symbolism, irony, and allusion) on the meaning of literary texts.
objectLabel: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.

subjectLabel: Interpret the effect of the author's craft (for example, word choice, sentence structure, the use of figurative language, and the use of dialogue) on the meaning of literary texts.

subjectLabel: Create multiple-paragraph compositions that have an introduction and a conclusion, include a coherent thesis, and use support (for example, definitions and descriptions).

subjectLabel: Design and carry out research projects by selecting a topic, constructing inquiry questions, accessing resources, evaluating credibility, and organizing information.
objectLabel: Conduct short as well as more sustained research projects to answer a question (including a self-generated question) or solve a problem; narrow or broaden the inquiry when appropriate; synthesize multiple sources on the subject, demonstrating understanding of the subject under investigation.

subjectLabel: Design and carry out research projects by selecting a topic, constructing inquiry questions, accessing resources, evaluating credibility, and organizing information.
objectLabel: Conduct short as well as more sustained research projects to answer a question (including a self-generated question) or solve a problem; narrow or broaden the inquiry when appropriate; synthesize multiple sources on the subject, demonstrating understanding of the subject under investigation.

subjectLabel: Use direct quotations, paraphrasing, or summaries to incorporate into written, oral, auditory, or visual works the information gathered from a variety of research sources.
objectLabel: Gather relevant information from multiple authoritative print and digital sources, using advanced searches effectively; assess the strengths and limitations of each source in terms of the task, purpose, and audience; integrate information into the text selectively to maintain the flow of ideas, avoiding plagiarism and over-reliance on any one source and following a standard format for citation.

subjectLabel: Evaluate an author's use of genre to convey theme.
objectLabel: Determine two or more themes or central ideas of a text and analyze their development over the course of the text, including how they interact and build on one another to produce a complex account; provide an objective summary of the text.

subjectLabel: Analyze a given literary text to determine its theme.
objectLabel: Determine two or more themes or central ideas of a text and analyze their development over the course of the text, including how they interact and build on one another to produce a complex account; provide an objective summary of the text.

subjectLabel: Analyze the relationship among character, plot, conflict, and theme in a given literary text.
objectLabel: Analyze the impact of the author's choices regarding how to develop and relate elements of a story or drama (e.g., where a story is set, how the action is ordered, how the characters are introduced and developed).

subjectLabel: Explain how British history and culture have influenced the use and development of the English language.
objectLabel: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in the text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including words with multiple meanings or language that is particularly fresh, engaging, or beautiful. (Include Shakespeare as well as other authors.)

subjectLabel: Explain how American history and culture have influenced the use and development of the English language.
objectLabel: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in the text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including words with multiple meanings or language that is particularly fresh, engaging, or beautiful. (Include Shakespeare as well as other authors.)

subjectLabel: Evaluate devices of figurative language (including extended metaphor, oxymoron, pun, and paradox).
objectLabel: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in the text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including words with multiple meanings or language that is particularly fresh, engaging, or beautiful. (Include Shakespeare as well as other authors.)

subjectLabel: Evaluate devices of figurative language (including extended metaphor, oxymoron, pun, and paradox).
objectLabel: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in the text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including words with multiple meanings or language that is particularly fresh, engaging, or beautiful. (Include Shakespeare as well as other authors.)

subjectLabel: Use context clues to determine the meaning of technical terms and other unfamiliar words.
objectLabel: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in the text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including words with multiple meanings or language that is particularly fresh, engaging, or beautiful. (Include Shakespeare as well as other authors.)

subjectLabel: Use context clues to determine the meaning of technical terms and other unfamiliar words.
objectLabel: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in the text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including words with multiple meanings or language that is particularly fresh, engaging, or beautiful. (Include Shakespeare as well as other authors.)

subjectLabel: Use context clues to determine the meaning of technical terms and other unfamiliar words.
objectLabel: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in the text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including words with multiple meanings or language that is particularly fresh, engaging, or beautiful. (Include Shakespeare as well as other authors.)

subjectLabel: Evaluate an author's use of genre to convey theme.
objectLabel: Demonstrate knowledge of eighteenth-, nineteenth- and early-twentieth-century foundational works of American literature, including how two or more texts from the same period treat similar themes or topics.

subjectLabel: Evaluate an author's use of genre to convey theme.
objectLabel: Demonstrate knowledge of eighteenth-, nineteenth- and early-twentieth-century foundational works of American literature, including how two or more texts from the same period treat similar themes or topics.

subjectLabel: Evaluate the impact of point of view on literary texts.
objectLabel: Analyze a case in which grasping point of view requires distinguishing what is directly stated in a text from what is really meant (e.g., satire, sarcasm, irony, or understatement).

subjectLabel: Evaluate the impact of point of view on literary texts.
objectLabel: Analyze a case in which grasping point of view requires distinguishing what is directly stated in a text from what is really meant (e.g., satire, sarcasm, irony, or understatement).

subjectLabel: Compare/contrast literary texts from various genres (for example, poetry, drama, novels, and short stories).
objectLabel: Analyze multiple interpretations of a story, drama, or poem (e.g., recorded or live production of a play or recorded novel or poetry), evaluating how each version interprets the source text. (Include at least one play by Shakespeare and one play by an American dramatist.)

subjectLabel: Read independently for extended periods of time for pleasure.
objectLabel:
By the end of grade 11, read and comprehend literature, including stories, dramas, and poems, in the grades 11—CCR text complexity band proficiently, with scaffolding as needed at the high end of the range.

By the end of grade 12, read and comprehend literature, including stories, dramas, and poems, at the high end of the grades 11—CCR text complexity band independently and proficiently.

subjectLabel: Read independently for extended periods of time for pleasure.
objectLabel:
By the end of grade 11, read and comprehend literature, including stories, dramas, and poems, in the grades 11—CCR text complexity band proficiently, with scaffolding as needed at the high end of the range.

By the end of grade 12, read and comprehend literature, including stories, dramas, and poems, at the high end of the grades 11—CCR text complexity band independently and proficiently.

subjectLabel: Compare/contrast information within and across texts to draw conclusions and make inferences.
objectLabel: Cite strong and thorough textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text, including determining where the text leaves matters uncertain.

subjectLabel: Compare/contrast ideas within and across literary texts to make inferences.
objectLabel: Cite strong and thorough textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text, including determining where the text leaves matters uncertain.

subjectLabel: Compare/contrast information within and across texts to draw conclusions and make inferences.
objectLabel: Cite strong and thorough textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text, including determining where the text leaves matters uncertain.

subjectLabel: Compare/contrast ideas within and across literary texts to make inferences.
objectLabel: Cite strong and thorough textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text, including determining where the text leaves matters uncertain.

subjectLabel: Analyze central ideas within and across informational texts.
objectLabel: Analyze a complex set of ideas or sequence of events and explain how specific individuals, ideas, or events interact and develop over the course of the text.

subjectLabel: Compare/contrast theses within and across informational texts.
objectLabel: Determine two or more central ideas of a text and analyze their development over the course of the text, including how they interact and build on one another to provide a complex analysis; provide an objective summary of the text.

subjectLabel: Summarize the central idea and supporting evidence of a given informational text.
objectLabel: Determine two or more central ideas of a text and analyze their development over the course of the text, including how they interact and build on one another to provide a complex analysis; provide an objective summary of the text.

subjectLabel: Analyze informational texts for author bias (including word choice, the exclusion and inclusion of particular information, and unsupported opinion).
objectLabel: Delineate and evaluate the reasoning in seminal U.S. texts, including the application of constitutional principles and use of legal reasoning (e.g., in U.S. Supreme Court majority opinions and dissents) and the premises, purposes, and arguments in works of public advocacy (e.g., The Federalist, presidential addresses).

subjectLabel: Analyze informational texts for author bias (including word choice, the exclusion and inclusion of particular information, and unsupported opinion).
objectLabel: Delineate and evaluate the reasoning in seminal U.S. texts, including the application of constitutional principles and use of legal reasoning (e.g., in U.S. Supreme Court majority opinions and dissents) and the premises, purposes, and arguments in works of public advocacy (e.g., The Federalist, presidential addresses).

subjectLabel: Use context clues to determine the meaning of technical terms and other unfamiliar words.
objectLabel: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze how an author uses and refines the meaning of a key term or terms over the course of a text (e.g., how Madison defines faction in Federalist No. 10).

subjectLabel: Use context clues to determine the meaning of technical terms and other unfamiliar words.
objectLabel: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze how an author uses and refines the meaning of a key term or terms over the course of a text (e.g., how Madison defines faction in Federalist No. 10).

subjectLabel: Read independently for extended periods of time to gain information.
objectLabel:
By the end of grade 11, read and comprehend literary nonfiction in the grades 11—CCR text complexity band proficiently, with scaffolding as needed at the high end of the range.
By the end of grade 12, read and comprehend literary nonfiction at the high end of the grades 11—CCR text complexity band independently and proficiently.

subjectLabel: Organize written works using prewriting techniques, discussions, graphic organizers, models, and outlines.
objectLabel: Develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach, focusing on addressing what is most significant for a specific purpose and audience.

subjectLabel: Organize written works using prewriting techniques, discussions, graphic organizers, models, and outlines.
objectLabel: Provide a conclusion that follows from and reflects on what is experienced, observed, or resolved over the course of the narrative.

subjectLabel: Organize written works using prewriting techniques, discussions, graphic organizers, models, and outlines.
objectLabel: Use precise words and phrases, telling details, and sensory language to convey a vivid picture of the experiences, events, setting, and/or characters.

subjectLabel: Organize written works using prewriting techniques, discussions, graphic organizers, models, and outlines.
objectLabel: Use a variety of techniques to sequence events so that they build on one another to create a coherent whole and build toward a particular tone and outcome (e.g., a sense of mystery, suspense, growth, or resolution).

subjectLabel: Organize written works using prewriting techniques, discussions, graphic organizers, models, and outlines.
objectLabel: Use narrative techniques, such as dialogue, pacing, description, reflection, and multiple plot lines, to develop experiences, events, and/or characters.

subjectLabel: Organize written works using prewriting techniques, discussions, graphic organizers, models, and outlines.
objectLabel: Engage and orient the reader by setting out a problem, situation, or observation and its significance, establishing one or multiple point(s) of view, and introducing a narrator and/or characters; create a smooth progression of experiences or events.

subjectLabel: Organize written works using prewriting techniques, discussions, graphic organizers, models, and outlines.
objectLabel: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, well-chosen details, and well-structured event sequences.

subjectLabel: Organize written works using prewriting techniques, discussions, graphic organizers, models, and outlines.
objectLabel: Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the information or explanation presented (e.g., articulating implications or the significance of the topic).

subjectLabel: Organize written works using prewriting techniques, discussions, graphic organizers, models, and outlines.
objectLabel: Establish and maintain a formal style and objective tone while attending to the norms and conventions of the discipline in which they are writing.

subjectLabel: Organize written works using prewriting techniques, discussions, graphic organizers, models, and outlines.
objectLabel: Use precise language, domain-specific vocabulary, and techniques such as metaphor, simile, and analogy to manage the complexity of the topic.

subjectLabel: Organize written works using prewriting techniques, discussions, graphic organizers, models, and outlines.
objectLabel: Use appropriate and varied transitions and syntax to link the major sections of the text, create cohesion, and clarify the relationships among complex ideas and concepts.

subjectLabel: Organize written works using prewriting techniques, discussions, graphic organizers, models, and outlines.
objectLabel: Develop the topic thoroughly by selecting the most significant and relevant facts, extended definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples appropriate to the audience's knowledge of the topic.

subjectLabel: Organize written works using prewriting techniques, discussions, graphic organizers, models, and outlines.
objectLabel: Introduce a topic; organize complex ideas, concepts, and information so that each new element builds on that which precedes it to create a unified whole; include formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., figures, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension.

subjectLabel: Organize written works using prewriting techniques, discussions, graphic organizers, models, and outlines.
objectLabel: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine and convey complex ideas, concepts, and information clearly and accurately through the effective selection, organization, and analysis of content.

subjectLabel: Organize written works using prewriting techniques, discussions, graphic organizers, models, and outlines.
objectLabel: Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the argument presented.

subjectLabel: Organize written works using prewriting techniques, discussions, graphic organizers, models, and outlines.
objectLabel: Establish and maintain a formal style and objective tone while attending to the norms and conventions of the discipline in which they are writing.

subjectLabel: Organize written works using prewriting techniques, discussions, graphic organizers, models, and outlines.
objectLabel: Use words, phrases, and clauses as well as varied syntax to link the major sections of the text, create cohesion, and clarify the relationships between claim(s) and reasons, between reasons and evidence, and between claim(s) and counterclaims.

subjectLabel: Organize written works using prewriting techniques, discussions, graphic organizers, models, and outlines.
objectLabel: Develop claim(s) and counterclaims fairly and thoroughly, supplying the most relevant evidence for each while pointing out the strengths and limitations of both in a manner that anticipates the audience's knowledge level, concerns, values, and possible biases.

subjectLabel: Organize written works using prewriting techniques, discussions, graphic organizers, models, and outlines.
objectLabel: Introduce precise, knowledgeable claim(s), establish the significance of the claim(s), distinguish the claim(s) from alternate or opposing claims, and create an organization that logically sequences claim(s), counterclaims, reasons, and evidence.

subjectLabel: Organize written works using prewriting techniques, discussions, graphic organizers, models, and outlines.
objectLabel: Write arguments to support claims in an analysis of substantive topics or texts, using valid reasoning and relevant and sufficient evidence.

subjectLabel: Create multiple-paragraph compositions that have an introduction and a conclusion, include a coherent thesis, and use support (for example, definitions and descriptions).
objectLabel: Produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience.

objectLabel: Write arguments to support claims in an analysis of substantive topics or texts, using valid reasoning and relevant and sufficient evidence.

subjectLabel: Revise writing to improve clarity, tone, voice, content, and the development of ideas. (See Instructional Appendix: Composite Writing Matrix.)
objectLabel: Develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach, focusing on addressing what is most significant for a specific purpose and audience.

subjectLabel: Revise writing to improve clarity, tone, voice, content, and the development of ideas. (See Instructional Appendix: Composite Writing Matrix.)
objectLabel: Provide a conclusion that follows from and reflects on what is experienced, observed, or resolved over the course of the narrative.

subjectLabel: Revise writing to improve clarity, tone, voice, content, and the development of ideas. (See Instructional Appendix: Composite Writing Matrix.)
objectLabel: Use precise words and phrases, telling details, and sensory language to convey a vivid picture of the experiences, events, setting, and/or characters.

subjectLabel: Revise writing to improve clarity, tone, voice, content, and the development of ideas. (See Instructional Appendix: Composite Writing Matrix.)
objectLabel: Use a variety of techniques to sequence events so that they build on one another to create a coherent whole and build toward a particular tone and outcome (e.g., a sense of mystery, suspense, growth, or resolution).

subjectLabel: Revise writing to improve clarity, tone, voice, content, and the development of ideas. (See Instructional Appendix: Composite Writing Matrix.)

subjectLabel:
Use grammatical conventions of written Standard American English to clarify and enhance meaning including
  • subject-verb agreement,
  • pronoun-antecedent agreement,
  • agreement of nouns and their modifiers,
  • verb formation,
  • pronoun case,
  • formation of comparative or superlative adjectives and adverbs, and
  • idiomatic usage.
(See Instructional Appendix: Composite Writing Matrix.)
objectLabel: Develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach, focusing on addressing what is most significant for a specific purpose and audience.

subjectLabel:
Edit written pieces for the correct mechanics and usage of written Standard American English including
  • internal and end of sentence punctuation,
  • commas to indicate appositives,
  • word placement to avoid ambiguity,
  • appropriate coordination and subordination,
  • relationship between and among clauses,
  • placement of modifiers, and
  • shifts in construction.
(See Instructional Appendix: Composite Writing Matrix.)
objectLabel: Develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach, focusing on addressing what is most significant for a specific purpose and audience.

subjectLabel: Design and carry out research projects by selecting a topic, constructing inquiry questions, accessing resources, evaluating credibility, and organizing information.
objectLabel: Conduct short as well as more sustained research projects to answer a question (including a self-generated question) or solve a problem; narrow or broaden the inquiry when appropriate; synthesize multiple sources on the subject, demonstrating understanding of the subject under investigation.

subjectLabel: Design and carry out research projects by selecting a topic, constructing inquiry questions, accessing resources, evaluating credibility, and organizing information.
objectLabel: Conduct short as well as more sustained research projects to answer a question (including a self-generated question) or solve a problem; narrow or broaden the inquiry when appropriate; synthesize multiple sources on the subject, demonstrating understanding of the subject under investigation.

subjectLabel: Use a standardized system of documentation (including a list of sources with full publication information and the use of intext citations) to properly credit the work of others.
objectLabel: Gather relevant information from multiple authoritative print and digital sources, using advanced searches effectively; assess the strengths and limitations of each source in terms of the specific task, purpose, and audience; integrate information into the text selectively to maintain the flow of ideas, avoiding plagiarism and over-reliance on any one source and following a standard format for citation.
